cardinality.description: A relationshipâ€™s cardinality defines the maximum number of entities of one type that can be associated with an entity of another type. (I.E. 1:M -> A user has many sites)

existence.description: Allow an entity to be created with/without classifying its subtypes. (I.E. 'mandatory' setting -> (site, environment, binding)), (I.E. 'optional' feature -> (site, user, organization))

degree.description: Relationships can be classified by the number of entity types involved.

sub_type.description: If entities are allowed to be no more than one subtype, then the subtypes are said to be disjoint (I.E. bindings -> (appserver, dbserver, etc)). If entities can be classified as several subtypes, then the subtypes are said to be overlapping (I.E user -> (holder, owner, user_in_charge, etc.)).

aggregate.description: When an entity is made up of several different types of other entities (I.E. sites -> (settings, features, etc.) ).

weak.description: A weak relation exists because some other relation to an entity exists. (I.E. sites -> (bindings, loadbalancers, etc.))
